awd_titl_txt: STEM Education 2026: Workshop on Assessment, Evaluation, and Accreditation
awd_abstract_narration:
Improving and enhancing undergraduate STEM education is crucial to the economic well-being of the nation. Additionally, innovation is a critical piece of an effective STEM education of the future. In this project, Minnesota State University (a comprehensive, public institution) and Normandale Community College (a neighboring two-year college) will collaborate to host a workshop that will bring together participants and researchers from multiple STEM fields who are working to evaluate STEM education innovation. Workshop participants will examine barriers, both real and perceived, in program and institutional accreditation and examine how such barriers affect innovation for the STEM student experience. The synthesis of discipline-based perspectives on benefits and challenges related to assessment, evaluation, and accreditation in STEM education and their relationships will also be a focus of the workshop.   

The goal of the proposed workshop will be to examine how assessment, evaluation, and accreditation have allowed innovation in STEM education to develop, persist, and/or perish. A key contribution of this workshop to the improvement of STEM education will be bringing together participants from life sciences, physical sciences, mathematics, engineering, and computing to discuss issues and challenges related to assessment, evaluation, and accreditation. Case studies from evidence-based effective STEM programs at institutions throughout the country will be included in the workshop. The workshop will provide a forum to examine these exemplary STEM undergraduate programs, including examining possible successes and failures in accreditation of such innovative programs. By synthesizing knowledge and experiences across STEM fields and disseminating this information broadly, this work will influence further discussions about ways to improve STEM education in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Three significant outcomes addressing the quality of STEM education in the United States came from this project. The first was a workshop that brought together 37 people from a variety of STEM disciplines (life sciences, physical sciences, mathematics, engineering, engineering technology and computing), institutions, and accreditation bodies to discuss the relationship between innovation and evaluation in STEM as well as the challenges of supporting innovation. Case studies were presented from the University of Bath's (UK) institutional-level curriculum transformation project, from Worcester Polytechnic Institute's interdisciplinary degree in robotics engineering, and from Minnesota State University, Mankato's project-based Iron Range Engineering and Twin Cities Engineering programs that focus on the "how" of meeting graduation outcomes. All cases strive for deeper integration of foundational STEM knowledge with the skills and values needed to adapt to and address future challenges. Key findings showed that addressing the whole student in multiple ways would be crucial to future success of STEM learning, and paths for future exploration were outlined. Second, the findings of the workshop are published in the Report from the STEM 2026 Workshop on Assessment, Evaluation, and Accreditation available at https://cornerstone.lib.mnsu.edu/reports/1/. 

Because of the global pandemic, a planned follow-up meeting of the workshop participants did not happen, although discipline-related conversations continue in different ways. Building on work from the Future Substance of STEM Education (DGE-1747486), the third outcome of this support was a curriculum development project "STEM 2026: Curricula Grounded in Assessment" that focused on innovative curriculum, interdisciplinary learning, and assessment. Three different groups with representatives from three institutions produced plans and proposals that met the call for incorporating humanistic knowledge (including ethics and other humanistic considerations), meta knowledge (including skills, mindsets and attitudes related to core STEM knowledge), and foundational knowledge (including traditional STEM disciplinary knowledge) with assessment build into the curricular design.

At California State University, Los Angeles, two teams addressed different ways to support students. One team developed modules to integrate ethical issues into STEM and business curricula for learning about Artificial Intelligence. The other developed a rapid feedback process to support and cultivate an asset-based academic eco-system.

At Minnesota State University, Mankato, a team created a plan for a project-based Integrated STEAM (IS) degree that connects multiple disciplines with industry to offer an adaptable program that is customizable to the unique situation and needs of individual students. The team included a representative from Saint Paul College, a two-year college in the same university system to insure that equitable pathways for transfer students was incorporated in the foundation of the degree.
